Award.AbstractNarration:
Astronomers now believe that the centers of most galaxies harbor extremely large black holes, containing millions to billions of times the mass of our Sun. These black holes can be detected only through their influence on their neighbors, including stars, dust, and gas. The only way to study this influence, and especially to interpret the astronomical observations, is through complex computer simulations. This project will develop several new approaches to understanding the behavior of stars near black holes, emphasizing the observable consequences. Much of the detailed work will be carried out by junior scientists who will thus undergo extensive advanced training in theoretical astrophysics.

Particular effects of importance include flares from stars that wander too close to the black hole, from active galactic nuclei fed by gaseous accretion disks orbiting the black hole, and from the influence of the black hole's gravity on the kinematics of nearby stars. As noted, this research will develop novel numerical tools to study the dynamics of stellar systems near black holes, and in addition will study the evolution of warps in accretion disks and look for relativistic effects in the spectra of quasars. Specifically, this work will: (i) explore novel orbit integrators for the gravitational N-body problem, possibly allowing much larger time-steps; (ii) investigate the behavior of warped accretion disks, where self-gravity, viscous stresses, and the Lense-Thirring effect, are all important in determining the disk shape; (iii) develop an "N-wire" code (which averages over orbital phase by representing each star as an eccentric wire) and use it to study relaxation and stability of stellar systems near a black hole and the eccentric stellar disk at the center of M31; (iv) implement an "N-ring" code (which represents each star as an annular disk) and use it to model stars near the Galactic center; and (v) look for relativistic effects in the velocity offsets between broad and narrow emission lines in a large sample of quasars. The project will contribute to the advanced training of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in theoretical astrophysics, and will help to interpret results from existing and planned flagship telescope projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Astronomers are certain that black holes of up to few billion times the mass of the Sun are found at the centers of many galaxies. The broad goal of the research supported by this grant is to investigate the behavior of stars and gas orbiting close to these black holes, in order to answer such questions as: (i) where does the fuel for quasars come from? (ii) do tidal disruptions of stars by the black hole produce the flares in luminosity that have been detected at the centers of many galaxies? (iii) can we predict the equilibrium distribution of stars around a black hole? (iv) are mergers of stellar remnants near the black holes the source of the gravitational-wave signals that have been detected by LIGO?
As background, I wrote a semi-popular description of the relation between quasars and black holes: "The odd couple: quasars and black holes", Daedalus143, no. 4, 103-113.
Much evidence suggests that the gas disks found around black holes are warped. The standard model model attributes the shape of the warp to the competition between relativistic torques from the central black hole and viscous angular-momentum transport within the disk. With postdoctoral fellow Shane Davis, I showed that this description is incomplete, and that torques from the companion star (for black holes in binary star systems) or the self-gravity of the disk (for quasars) can play a major role in determining the properties of the warped disk. The inclusion of these effects can lead to the excitation of short-wavelength bending waves, discontinuities in the disk orientation, or still unexplored time-dependent behavior. 
The  emission lines in quasar spectra have velocity widths of a few percent of the speed of light, so special- and general-relativistic effects have a significant influence on the line profile. With my collaborators I have determined the redshift of the broad lines in the quasar rest frame for over 20,000 quasars from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey quasar catalog. The mean redshift as a function of line width is approximately consistent with the relativistic redshift that is expected if the line originates in a randomly oriented Keplerian disk that is obscured when the inclination of the disk to the line of sight exceeds ~30°-45°, consistent with simple "unification" models of active galactic nuclei. This result also implies that the net line-of-sight inflow/outflow velocities in the broad-line region are much less than the Keplerian velocity when averaged over a large sample of quasars with a given line width.
Postdoctoral fellow Ben Bar-Or has worked with Tal Alexander (Weizmann Institute) on stellar dynamics near the loss cone of a black hole, taking into account Newtonian precession due to enclosed stellar mass, precession due to general relativity, dissipation by gravitational waves, two-body relaxation, and resonant relaxation. A primary goal of this work is to establish the tidal disruption and consumption rates for stars.
With graduate student Kedron Silsbee I have investigated the possibility that the binary black hole system whose merger led to the gravitational wave signal detected by LIGO was formed by long-term oscillations in a triple-star system containing massive stars. Preliminary calculations show that the rate of formation by this mechanism is adequate so long as the velocity kick during supernova events is not too large. 
With postdoctoral fellow B. Kocsis I investigated the equilibria of stellar systems surrounding black holes. For a wide range of ages this equilibrium is determined by a form of "resonant relaxation" that relaxes the orientation of stellar orbits without changing their shape and size. This relaxation mechanism can successfully reproduce the warp (amplitude and direction) in the disk of young stars in the Galactic center, as well as the appearance of a structure resembling a second disk.
I have collaborated with Naveen Jingade and Tarun Saini at the Indian Institute of Science in Bangalore, to study the effect of slow growth of a central black hole on the surrounding stellar system. The black-hole growth leads to a central cusp or “excess light." The  excess stellar mass in the cusp scales approximately linearly with the black hole mass, and is typically 0.5–0.85 times the black hole mass. Our results show that adiabatic growth is not sufficient to explain the excess light seen in many nearby elliptical galaxies but may strongly influence the structure of nuclear star clusters in spheroidal galaxies if they contain black holes.
